title: 103_hr4304
content: The "Public Housing Improvement Act of 1994" repeals the 1-for-1 replacement requirement in the United States Housing Act of 1937. The amendments take effect on October 1, 1994, allowing the use of modernization funds for cost-effective new construction. Section 14 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow for the replacement of existing public housing projects with new construction at a cost not exceeding the cost of improving the existing units. This amendment also includes provisions for replacing projects through new construction. Section 14 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 allows for the replacement of public housing projects with new construction, with estimated costs for improvements and replacements. Amendments include provisions for replacing projects through new construction. Amendments to Section 14 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 allow for the replacement of public housing projects with new construction, specifying estimated costs for improvements and replacements. Amendments to Section 14 of the United States Housing Act of 1937 now permit public housing agencies to use financial assistance for new construction projects to replace existing eligible projects, with provisions for demolition or disposition of the replaced projects. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows public housing agencies to use financial assistance for new construction projects to replace existing eligible projects, with provisions for demolition or disposition of the replaced projects if certain conditions are met. SEC. 4. MANDATORY PRIVATE MANAGEMENT OF CHRONICALLY TROUBLED PUBLIC HOUSING AGENCIES. Section 6(j) of the United States Housing Act of 1937 is amended to allow the Secretary to transfer management of troubled public housing projects to a private entity if certain criteria are met. The Secretary can transfer management of public housing to a private entity after consulting with residents. A contract must be made meeting specific requirements, including resident consultation and potential funding for improvements. The Secretary can transfer management of public housing to a private entity under specific conditions, including resident consultation and potential funding for improvements. Section 25(j) provisions apply to managers of eligible housing. Management must be transferred back to the public housing agency once the troubled designation is removed.
